Summary: The proposal aims to develop a dynamic, hardware-aware distributed training infrastructure for large-scale AI models, addressing inefficiencies in communication overhead, memory utilization, and hardware heterogeneity. It proposes adaptive communication scheduling, memory-centric execution, and a hardware-abstracted backend, with a detailed experimental plan to validate the approach.
Strengths: Addresses a critical and timely problem in AI research.
Well-motivated hypothesis building on recent work.
Comprehensive experimental plan with clear benchmarks.
Proposes innovative solutions like adaptive communication scheduling and memory-centric execution.
Weaknesses: Lacks depth in addressing potential technical challenges.
Execution plan could benefit from more detailed risk mitigation strategies.
Feasibility of reinforcement learning-based policy selection in real-time is unclear.
Integration complexities of the hardware-abstracted backend are not fully explored.
Questions: How will the reinforcement learning-based policy selection handle real-time constraints?
What are the specific challenges in integrating the hardware-abstracted backend with diverse accelerators?
How will the proposed memory allocator handle extreme cases of memory fragmentation?
What are the fallback mechanisms if the adaptive scheduler fails to converge on an optimal policy?
Limitations: Potential scalability issues with the adaptive scheduler in very large clusters.
Uncertainty in the performance portability across heterogeneous hardware.
Risk of increased complexity in the unified abstraction layer.
